ContentsItem.ContentsTitle: Standards for health and sustainable food in hospitals

Para.Text: Make provision for the regulation of food standards in hospitals.

Be it enacted by the Queen’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows:—

P1group.Title: Standards for health and sustainable food in hospitals

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State shall, not later than 12 months after this Act comes into force, ensure that representatives from government, industry, professional bodies and relevant sectors agree standards for the procurement of healthy and sustainable food for patients in hospital.
The Secretary of State shall approve and publish the standards.
The standards must—

P3para.Text: take into account the varying nutritional and feeding support needs of different categories of patients.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State will include the standards published under subsection (2) in Regulation 14 of the Health and Social Care Act 2008 (Regulated Activities) Regulations 2010.
The Secretary of State shall keep the standards under review and may revise them when the Secretary of State considers it appropriate to do so.
Save for the provision in section 4 of this Act, this Act applies to hospital food provided to patients at a hospital.

P1para.Text: The Secretary of State shall publish an annual report on—

P3para.Text: the extent to which the Care and Quality Commission has found the standards to have been adopted by hospitals; and
the further actions that the Secretary of State proposes to take to ensure widespread adoption of the standards by hospitals.

P1para.Text: In ensuring that government, industry, professional bodies and relevant sectors prepare the standards, the Secretary of State shall specify the promotion of the following objectives—

P3para.Text: promoting the consumption of food which supports the health and recovery of patients;

supporting the sustainability of hospital food by taking account of greenhouse gas emissions and other pollutants associated with all stages of the food chain, biodiversity, animal welfare, fair trade, food waste and sustainable development in food and farming.

P2para.Text: This Act does not apply in relation to any part of hospital premises which is under the control of another organisation by virtue of—

P3para.Text: any formal or informal arrangement with a voluntary or charitable organisation.

P2para.Text: Nothing in this Act applies to food provided—

P3para.Text: as part of celebrations to mark religious or cultural occasions;
as part of a diet prescribed by a patient’s medical professional.

P2para.Text: Section 61 of the Health and Social Care Act 2008 (inspections carried out for registration purposes) is amended as follows.
Subsection (1)(a) is repealed.
In subsection (1)(b) for “they are to be carried out” substitute “inspections are to be carried out under section 60 for the purposes of the Commission’s functions under Chapter 2”.
After subsection (1) insert—
Inspections are to be carried out under section 60 for the purposes of the Commission’s functions under Chapter 2 and the frequency of inspections must not be less than once a year.
In this section “service providers” has the same meaning as in the Health and Social Care Act 2008.
Any failure of a service provider to comply with section 1 shall result in a suspension of their registration as outlined in section 18(2) of the Health and Social Care Act 2008.

The Secretary of State may give direction to the Care and Quality Commission, under section 82(1) of the Health and Social Care Act 2008, if it fails properly to discharge functions set out in this Act.
The Secretary of State must consult such persons as the Secretary of State considers appropriate for the purposes of considering the proposals in section 1.
This Act shall not come into force until consultation under subsection (1) has been fulfilled and the Secretary of State has reported to Parliament the outcome of such consultations.

Para.Text: “industry” means any company, or body representing the interests of companies, whose functions are connected to the supply of food or related services in, or for consumption in, England;

“professional bodies” means non-profit organisations that represent the interests of their members, and whose functions are connected to the health, social, animal welfare or environmental impacts resulting from the supply of food to patients in hospital in England;
“relevant sectors” means other bodies, including those within the voluntary sector, which represent the interests of—
“hospital” means any publicly-funded hospital, whose functions include the procurement of food in, or for consumption in, hospitals in England;
“the standards’ objectives” means the objectives set out in section 3.

P2para.Text: This Act may be cited as the Health and Social Care (Amendment) (Food Standards) Act 2013.
This Act comes into force at the end of the period of six months beginning with the day on which it is passed save for section 2 which comes into force at the
end of the period of twelve months beginning with the day on which this Act is passed.
This Act extends to England.
